1using System;
2using System.Collections.Generic;
3​
4namespace TechnicalIndicators
5{
6 /// <summary>
7 /// Fisher Transform
8 /// </summary>
9 /// <remarks>
10 /// Transforms price data into a Gaussian normal distribution.
11 /// Used to identify sharp turning points.
12 /// <list type="bullet">
13 /// <item><description>Fisher Line crosses Trigger Line = Potential reversal.</description></item>
14 /// </list>
15 /// </remarks>
16 public class FisherTransform
17 {
18 public int Period { get; }
19 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
20 public List<decimal?> Trigger { get; } = new();
21​
22 public FisherTransform(int period = 10)
23 {
24 Period = period;
25 }
26​
27 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
28 {
29 Values.Clear();
30 Trigger.Clear();
31​
32 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
33 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
34​
35 decimal previousValue = 0;
36 decimal previousFisher = 0;
37​
38 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
39 {
40 if (i < Period - 1)
41 {
42 Values.Add(null);
43 Trigger.Add(null);
44 continue;
45 }
46​
47 // Step 1: Normalize Price to -1..1 range based on Period Min/Max
48 decimal highest = decimal.MinValue;
49 decimal lowest = decimal.MaxValue;
50​
51 for (int j = i - Period + 1; j <= i; j++)
52 {
53 decimal hl2 = (candleList[j].High + candleList[j].Low) / 2;
54 if (hl2 > highest) highest = hl2;
55 if (hl2 < lowest) lowest = hl2;
56 }
57​
58 decimal hl2Current = (candleList[i].High + candleList[i].Low) / 2;
59 decimal range = highest - lowest;
60​
61 decimal value;
62 if (range == 0)
63 {
64 value = 0;
65 }
66 else
67 {
68 decimal normalized = 2 * ((hl2Current - lowest) / range) - 1;
69 normalized = Math.Max(-0.999m, Math.Min(0.999m, normalized)); // Clamp to avoid Log error
70 value = 0.5m * previousValue + 0.5m * normalized; // Smooth
71 }
72​
73 // Step 2: Fisher Transformation Logic
74 decimal fisher = 0.5m * (decimal)Math.Log((double)((1 + value) / (1 - value)));
75 fisher = previousFisher * 0.5m + fisher; // Smooth
76​
77 Trigger.Add(previousFisher);
78 Values.Add(fisher);
79​
80 previousValue = value;
81 previousFisher = fisher;
82 }
83 }
84​
85 public static (List<decimal?> fisher, List<decimal?> trigger) Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period = 10)
86 {
87 var ft = new FisherTransform(period);
88 ft.Calculate(candles);
89 return (ft.Values, ft.Trigger);
90 }
91 }
92}

1// =============================================================================
2// Logic Breakdown (FisherTransform)
3// =============================================================================
4//
5// This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6// Fisher Transform technical indicator.
7// We explain *why* code is written this way and *how* data transforms
8// line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
9//
10// [Core Concepts]
11//
12// 1. Assumption of Normal Distribution
13// [Why] Financial data is often non-Gaussian (has "fat tails"), making
14// statistical analysis tricky.
15// [What] John Ehlers (2002) applied the Fisher Transform to reshape price
16// data into a Normal (Bell Curve) Distribution.
17// [Goal] By normalizing the data, extreme price moves (turning points) become
18// very distinct "spikes" that are easier to identify.
19//
20// 2. The Transformation Steps
21// Step A: Normalize price to range [-1, +1].
22// Step B: Apply Transform: y = 0.5 * ln((1+x) / (1-x)).
23// - If x is near 0, y is near 0.
24// - If x approaches 1, y shoots to +Infinity.
25// - If x approaches -1, y shoots to -Infinity.
26//
27// [Visual Plan]
28// Price: [Non-Linear, trend-based, noisy]
29// Normalized: [Constrained to -1...1, like an oscillator]
30// Fisher: [Explodes at extremes, sharp turning points]
31//
32// =============================================================================
33​
34using System;
35using System.Collections.Generic;
36​
37namespace TechnicalIndicators
38{
39 // =============================================================================
40 // Logic Explanation: OHLCV Data Container
41 // =============================================================================
42 public readonly record struct CandleData(DateTime Timestamp, decimal Open, decimal High, decimal Low, decimal Close, long Volume);
43​
44 // =============================================================================
45 // Logic Explanation: Fisher Transform Class
46 // =============================================================================
47 public class FisherTransform
48 {
49 // -------------------------------------------------------------
50 // Logic Explanation: Configuration & Outputs
51 // -------------------------------------------------------------
52 public int Period { get; }
53
54 // The main Fisher line
55 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
56
57 // The Trigger line (usually Fisher lagged by 1 bar)
58 public List<decimal?> Trigger { get; } = new();
59​
60 // =============================================================================
61 // Logic Explanation: Constructor
62 // =============================================================================
63 public FisherTransform(int period = 10)
64 {
65 if (period <= 0)
66 throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException(nameof(period), "Period must be greater than 0");
67 Period = period;
68 }
69​
70 // =============================================================================
71 // Logic Explanation: Main Calculation Method
72 // =============================================================================
73 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
74 {
75 // -------------------------------------------------------------
76 // Step 1: Cleanup & Setup
77 // -------------------------------------------------------------
78 Values.Clear();
79 Trigger.Clear();
80​
81 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
82 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
83​
84 // -------------------------------------------------------------
85 // Step 2: Recursive State Variables
86 //
87 // [Why] The Ehlers' formula is heavily smoothed using previous values.
88 // We need to persist 'previousValue' and 'previousFisher'.
89 // -------------------------------------------------------------
90 decimal previousValue = 0; // Smoothed Normalized Value
91 decimal previousFisher = 0; // Smoothed Fisher Value
92​
93 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
94 {
95 // -------------------------------------------------------------
96 // Phase A: Insufficient Data
97 // -------------------------------------------------------------
98 if (i < Period - 1)
99 {
100 Values.Add(null);
101 Trigger.Add(null);
102 continue;
103 }
104​
105 // -------------------------------------------------------------
106 // Phase B: Get HighestHigh and LowestLow over Period
107 //
108 // [Why] To normalize today's price, we need to know the bounds
109 // of the recent playing field.
110 // -------------------------------------------------------------
111 decimal highest = decimal.MinValue;
112 decimal lowest = decimal.MaxValue;
113​
114 // Loop back 'Period' bars
115 for (int j = i - Period + 1; j <= i; j++)
116 {
117 // Ehlers uses (High + Low) / 2 as the price proxy
118 decimal hl2 = (candleList[j].High + candleList[j].Low) / 2;
119 if (hl2 > highest) highest = hl2;
120 if (hl2 < lowest) lowest = hl2;
121 }
122​
123 decimal hl2Current = (candleList[i].High + candleList[i].Low) / 2;
124 decimal range = highest - lowest;
125 decimal value;
126​
127 // -------------------------------------------------------------
128 // Phase C: Normalize to [-1, 1]
129 // -------------------------------------------------------------
130 if (range == 0)
131 {
132 value = 0; // Avoid divide by zero
133 }
134 else
135 {
136 // Map Price to range [-1, 1]
137 // (x - Min) / Range -> [0, 1]
138 // 2 * [0, 1] - 1 -> [-1, 1]
139 decimal normalized = 2 * ((hl2Current - lowest) / range) - 1;
140
141 // Clamp to just inside boundaries (-0.999 to 0.999)
142 // [Why] Because Log(1 - 1) = Log(0) = Undefined (-Infinity).
143 // We must prevent '1' or '-1' exactly.
144 normalized = Math.Max(-0.999m, Math.Min(0.999m, normalized));
145
146 // Apply Smoothing (Ehlers' Custom Smoothing)
147 // NewValue = 0.5 * Prev + 0.5 * Current
148 value = 0.5m * previousValue + 0.5m * normalized;
149 }
150​
151 // -------------------------------------------------------------
152 // Phase D: Fisher Transform (Log Method)
153 //
154 // [Formula] 0.5 * ln((1 + value) / (1 - value))
155 // -------------------------------------------------------------
156 // (1 + v) / (1 - v) is always positive since |v| < 1.
157 double logTerm = Math.Log((double)((1 + value) / (1 - value)));
158 decimal fisher = 0.5m * (decimal)logTerm;
159​
160 // Apply Smoothing to Fisher result as well
161 fisher = previousFisher * 0.5m + fisher;
162​
163 // -------------------------------------------------------------
164 // Phase E: Store & Update
165 //
166 // [Trigger] The Trigger line is simply the *Previous* Fisher value.
167 // (Essentially a 1-bar lag).
168 // -------------------------------------------------------------
169 Trigger.Add(previousFisher);
170 Values.Add(fisher);
171​
172 previousValue = value;
173 previousFisher = fisher;
174 }
175 }
176​
177 // =============================================================================
178 // Logic Explanation: Static Convenience Wrapper
179 // =============================================================================
180 public static (List<decimal?> fisher, List<decimal?> trigger) Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period = 10)
181 {
182 var ft = new FisherTransform(period);
183 ft.Calculate(candles);
184 return (ft.Values, ft.Trigger);
185 }
186 }
187}

1import math

3class FisherTransform:
4 """
5 Fisher Transform
6 Normalizes price distribution.
7 """
8 def __init__(self, period=10):
9 self.period = period
10 self.values = []
11 self.trigger = []
12​
13 def calculate(self, candles):
14 self.values.clear()
15 self.trigger.clear()
16
17 if len(candles) == 0: return
18​
19 prev_val = 0.0
20 prev_fish = 0.0
21
22 for i in range(len(candles)):
23 if i < self.period - 1:
24 self.values.append(None)
25 self.trigger.append(None)
26 continue
27
28 # 1. Normalize Min/Max
29 subset = candles[i-self.period+1 : i+1]
30 highs = [c['high'] for c in subset]
31 lows = [c['low'] for c in subset]
32
33 # Using Min/Max of (H+L)/2 as per C# Code?
34 # C# Code:
35 # for j in i-P+1..i:
36 # hl2 = (c[j].H + c[j].L) / 2
37 # highest/lowest = Max/Min of hl2
38 # Let's stick to C# logic.
39
40 hl2s = [(c['high'] + c['low']) / 2.0 for c in subset]
41 highest = max(hl2s)
42 lowest = min(hl2s)
43
44 current_hl2 = (candles[i]['high'] + candles[i]['low']) / 2.0
45 rng = highest - lowest
46
47 if rng == 0:
48 val = 0.0
49 else:
50 norm = 2 * ((current_hl2 - lowest) / rng) - 1
51 norm = max(-0.999, min(0.999, norm))
52 val = 0.5 * prev_val + 0.5 * norm
53
54 # 2. Transform applied to 'val'
55 # 0.5 * ln((1+val)/(1-val))
56 fish = 0.5 * math.log((1 + val) / (1 - val))
57 fish = 0.5 * prev_fish + fish # Wait, C# code: `fisher = previousFisher * 0.5m + fisher`
58 # C# code line 74: `fisher = previousFisher * 0.5m + fisher;` -> This is WRONG in C# or my reading?
59 # Standard logic: Fisher = 0.5 * ln(...) + 0.5 * PrevFisher.
60 # C# line: `fisher = previousFisher * 0.5m + fisher;` (+= fisher means Adding the computed Log value? No)
61 # Line 73: `decimal fisher = 0.5m * Log(...)`
62 # Line 74: `fisher = previousFisher * 0.5m + fisher;`
63 # Yes, `fisher` (local var) holds the new Log component. Then we add 0.5*Prev.
64 # So `Result = 0.5 * Prev + 0.5 * Log(...)`.
65
66 self.trigger.append(prev_fish)
67 self.values.append(fish)
68
69 prev_val = val
70 prev_fish = fish
71​
72def calculate(candles, period=10):
73 ft = FisherTransform(period)
74 ft.calculate(candles)
75 return ft.values, ft.trigger

1# =============================================================================
2# Logic Breakdown (Fisher Transform)
3# =============================================================================
4#
5# This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6# Fisher Transform. We explain *why* code is written this way and *how* data
7# transforms line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
8#
9# [Core Concepts]
10# 1. Gaussian Normalization
11# Financial markets heavily "tail" (non-normal distribution).
12# Fisher Transform mathematically compresses price data into a
13# Gaussian (Bell Curve) probability distribution.
14# [Why] Makes turning points (extremes) distinct and sharp.
15#
16# 2. Domain Transformation
17# The formula uses Natural Logarithm (ln), which requires input between -1 and 1.
18# y = 0.5 * ln((1 + x) / (1 - x))
19# - If x approaches 1, y approaches Infinity.
20# - If x approaches -1, y approaches -Infinity.
21#
22# 3. Smoothing
23# Because the transform amplifies movements, the input and output are
24# heavily smoothed to prevent "whipsaws" (false signals).
25#
26# =============================================================================
27​
28import math
29​
30# -------------------------------------------------------------
31# Type-Level Explanation: FisherTransform (class)
32#
33# [Why] Stateful. Needs to remember previous values for smoothing.
34# [What] An oscillator that spots turning points.
35# [How] Normalizes price within the high-low range, then applies the Fisher Transform function to sharpen turning points and create a Gaussian probability distribution.
36# [Who] Swing Traders, Reversal Algorithms.
37# [Where] Heap.
38# -------------------------------------------------------------
39class FisherTransform:
40​
41 # -------------------------------------------------------------
42 # Logic Explanation: Indicator Configuration (Public Properties)
43 #
44 # [Why]
45 # Allow customization of the lookback window.
46 # Note: Fisher typically uses short periods (e.g., 10).
47 # -------------------------------------------------------------
48​
49 # -------------------------------------------------------------
50 # Constructor: __init__
51 #
52 # [Input]
53 # - period: int (Window size for Min/Max normalization)
54 #
55 # [Why]
56 # Initialize state buffers and validate input.
57 # -------------------------------------------------------------
58 def __init__(self, period=10):
59
60 # -------------------------------------------------------------
61 # Logic Step 1: Validation
62 # -------------------------------------------------------------
63 if period <= 0:
64 raise ValueError(f"Period must be greater than 0. Received: {period}")
65​
66 # -------------------------------------------------------------
67 # Variable Definition: Configuration
68 # -------------------------------------------------------------
69 self.period = period
70
71 # -------------------------------------------------------------
72 # Variable Definition: Output Buffers
73 # [What]
74 # - values: The main Fisher line.
75 # - trigger: The previous value of Fisher (Signal Line).
76 # -------------------------------------------------------------
77 self.values = []
78 self.trigger = []
79​
80​
81 # =============================================================================
82 # IPO: calculate
83 # =============================================================================
84 #
85 # [Input]
86 # - candles: list[dict] (Price data)
87 #
88 # [Process]
89 # 1. Reset State.
90 # 2. Iterate Data:
91 # a. Find High/Low range over 'period'.
92 # b. Normalize Price to -1..1 range.
93 # c. Logarithmic Transform (Fisher Formula).
94 # d. Update previous state for next iteration.
95 #
96 # [Output]
97 # - None (Populates self.values and self.trigger)
98 # =============================================================================
99 def calculate(self, candles):
100
101 # -------------------------------------------------------------
102 # Logic Step 1: Reset State
103 # -------------------------------------------------------------
104 self.values.clear()
105 self.trigger.clear()
106
107 if len(candles) == 0:
108 return
109​
110 # -------------------------------------------------------------
111 # Variable Definition: Recursive State
112 # [Why]
113 # The formulas strictly depend on T-1 (Yesterday's) values.
114 # We must track them outside the loop.
115 #
116 # - prev_norm: Normalized input from previous bar.
117 # - prev_fisher: Fisher output from previous bar.
118 # -------------------------------------------------------------
119 prev_norm = 0.0
120 prev_fisher = 0.0
121​
122 # -------------------------------------------------------------
123 # Logic Step 2: Main Loop
124 # -------------------------------------------------------------
125 for i in range(len(candles)):
126
127 # -------------------------------------------------------------
128 # Logic Step 2.1: Lookback Check
129 #
130 # [Decision]
131 # Do we have enough history to find Min/Max?
132 #
133 # [True Branch: Skip]
134 # - Not enough data. Pad with None.
135 # -------------------------------------------------------------
136 if i < self.period - 1:
137 self.values.append(None)
138 self.trigger.append(None)
139 continue
140​
141 # -------------------------------------------------------------
142 # Logic Step 2.2: Identify Range (Min/Max)
143 #
144 # [Why]
145 # To normalize relative price, we need the local ceiling (Max)
146 # and floor (Min).
147 # We use High/Low average (Midpoint) for stability.
148 # -------------------------------------------------------------
149 highest = float('-inf')
150 lowest = float('inf')
151
152 # Scan backward 'period' bars
153 # [Visual] Period=3, i=5
154 # Scan indices: 3, 4, 5
155 for j in range(i - self.period + 1, i + 1):
156 hl2 = (candles[j]['high'] + candles[j]['low']) / 2.0
157 if hl2 > highest:
158 highest = hl2
159 if hl2 < lowest:
160 lowest = hl2
161
162 # Current price point
163 current_hl2 = (candles[i]['high'] + candles[i]['low']) / 2.0
164 rng = highest - lowest
165
166 # -------------------------------------------------------------
167 # Logic Step 2.3: Normalize (Stochastic Position)
168 #
169 # [Why]
170 # Transform price dollars ($100..$105) into a ratio (-1..1).
171 #
172 # [Formula]
173 # Raw = 2 * ((Price - Min) / (Max - Min)) - 1
174 # - If Price == Min -> -1
175 # - If Price == Max -> +1
176 # - If Price == Mid -> 0
177 #
178 # [Smoothing]
179 # Value = 0.33 * Raw + 0.67 * PrevValue (Approx)
180 # (Here using 0.5/0.5 for simplicity per Ehlers variation)
181 # -------------------------------------------------------------
182 if rng == 0:
183 # Flat line case
184 normalized_raw = 0.0
185 else:
186 normalized_raw = 2.0 * ((current_hl2 - lowest) / rng) - 1.0
187
188 # Logic Step 2.3a: Clamp
189 # [Why] Math.log(x) requires x > 0.
190 # Our formula uses (1+x)/(1-x).
191 # - If x=1, DivByZero.
192 # - If x=-1, Log(0) -> -Infinity.
193 # We treat strict 1 as 0.999...
194 normalized_raw = max(-0.999, min(0.999, normalized_raw))
195
196 # Logic Step 2.3b: Smooth Input
197 # Recurse: Val[i] = 0.5 * Raw + 0.5 * Val[i-1]
198 fisher_input = 0.5 * normalized_raw + 0.5 * prev_norm
199
200 # Note: Re-Clamp might be needed if smoothing pushes it out,
201 # but usually safe since weighted average of (-1..1) is (-1..1).
202 if fisher_input > 0.99: fisher_input = 0.999
203 if fisher_input < -0.99: fisher_input = -0.999
204​
205 # -------------------------------------------------------------
206 # Logic Step 2.4: Fisher Transform Logarithm
207 #
208 # [Formula]
209 # y = 0.5 * ln( (1+x) / (1-x) )
210 #
211 # [Visual]
212 # x=0 -> ln(1) = 0
213 # x=0.5 -> ln(1.5/0.5)=ln(3) ~= 1.1... -> y=0.55
214 # x=0.9 -> ln(1.9/0.1)=ln(19)~= 2.9... -> y=1.45
215 # x=0.99 -> ln(199) ~= 5.3... -> y=2.65
216 # (Expands edges)
217 # -------------------------------------------------------------
218 fisher_raw = 0.5 * math.log((1 + fisher_input) / (1 - fisher_input))
219
220 # -------------------------------------------------------------
221 # Logic Step 2.5: Smooth Output
222 #
223 # [Formula]
224 # Fisher[i] = 0.5 * FisherRaw + 0.5 * Fisher[i-1]
225 # -------------------------------------------------------------
226 fisher_output = 0.5 * fisher_raw + 0.5 * prev_fisher
227
228 # -------------------------------------------------------------
229 # Logic Step 2.6: Store and Iterate
230 # -------------------------------------------------------------
231 # Trigger line is just the previous fisher value (Lag 1)
232 self.trigger.append(prev_fisher)
233 self.values.append(fisher_output)
234
235 # Update state variables for next loop (t -> t-1)
236 prev_norm = fisher_input
237 prev_fisher = fisher_output
238​
239​
240# =============================================================================
241# Functional Wrapper (Procedural Interface)
242# =============================================================================
243def calculate(candles, period=10):
244 """
245 Computes Fisher Transform.
246 """
247 # 1. Instantiation
248 ft = FisherTransform(period)
249
250 # 2. Execution
251 ft.calculate(candles)
252
253 # 3. Extraction
254 return ft.values, ft.trigger
